utterances: Schultheiss says Xcel has become a greener utility because of Boulder's takeover push, which is ongoing.
The city made Xcel a $70 million offer last month.
If San Francisco can get bankrupt PG&E to give up a crown jewel, it would likely pay much more - easily in the billions.
That could mean consumer rates go up at first, even if the ultimate goal is to give them more of a say.
For NPR News, I'm Lily Jamali in San Francisco.
Over the next few months, we're going to hear from people who are in pursuit of the American Dream through the most basic part of life - food.
Sometimes, the American Dream involves getting ahead in the world.
Today's story isn't like that but, it's still a traditional American Dream.
Think of the Puritans or the Shakers or the Amish - the uncompromising pursuit of a high ideal.
Dan Charles has the story.
On this day 18 years ago, David Fisher was in western Massachusetts, near the small town of Conway, visiting an old farm there.
But nobody was farming that land.
And I remember walking out at some point on New Year's Eve and in the moonlight, and it was all snowy and, you know, it was kind of like a blank canvas, right?
On that blank canvas, his mind painted a picture of what could be there alongside the South River.
And I could just see horses working the fields and children, you know, running around.
Today, it's all there - Natural Roots Farm.
To get to the farm, you have to leave the motorized world behind, cross the South River on a swinging footbridge.
And there in front of you are acres of growing vegetables, neatly laid out in rows.
It's early in the fall on this day.
The hillside beyond the field is glowing with red and yellow leaves.
It's idyllic, almost magical.
There's a woman checking on the fields, Anna Maclay.
I came originally as an apprentice in 2002 and totally fell in love with the land.
I just thought, I want to live here.
Her wish came true in a way she hadn't expected.
She and David Fisher fell in love, got married.
They now have two school-aged children, Leora and Gabriel.
It's a harvest day on the farm today.
David and Anna and a neighbor and two apprentices who are living and working on the farm for a year are filling a wagon with spinach and beets and cauliflower.
About 200 customers have bought shares in this farm's harvest, like Maggie Potter.
She arrives with her children to pick up her produce.
It's not only just having the vegetables and the good nourishment for our own bodies, but it's creating a really great community, meeting friends along the way.
But it's not all peace and happiness here at Natural Roots Farm.
The more I talk to David Fisher, the more I realize he is a very driven man.
He's driven in part by a desperate need to find some hope in the world.
He grew up in the suburbs north of New York City, in Westchester County.
He spent summers at a rustic camp in the Adirondacks.
The year when he was 15, that end-of-summer paradigm shift was more than he could take.
Well, Reid says he'll bring it back up when there's some kind of a compromise.
And there are the Republicans who say, look, you know, Harry Reid is doing a little theatrics here, a little showmanship.
There are some measures out there.

Perhaps, John Warner, the Republican from Virginia, is trying to work out a compromise that some Democrats may not feel is strong enough and that the troops would not be brought out quickly enough, but at least, he sort of come up with some kind of a compromise that would get a majority of the vote and right now, the two sides are far apart.
And then there's this question of is the majority 51 or is it 60?
I mean, they - the Democrats had to get 60 last night to shut off debate, and one of the things they were criticizing the Republicans for was forcing them to get to 60.
Well, the Republicans did the exact same thing years ago when the Republicans were in the majority.
I mean, I'm not going to equate the importance of the war in Iraq with some of the other issues on the bring-up right now.
But when the Republicans had a majority, there was a majority of support for Josh Bolton to be the U.N.
ambassador.
There was a majority support for some of the - President Bush's Supreme Court justices.
Democrats insisted on a 60-vote threshold, Republicans are doing the same thing right now.
Let's move on.
On the campaign front, Hillary Clinton and John Edwards got into trouble for a private strategy session.
What happened there?

This was after an NAACP conference, where all the Democratic candidates approached, and apparently, according to the stories here, John Edwards approached Hillary Clinton and said, look, we've got to limit the number of, I assume, the candidates that are here, it's getting unwieldy.
And Hillary Clinton responded and said, yes, our camp should talk about this.
Now, both backed down.

Well, actually, John Edwards said, no, I didn't want to eliminate the Kuciniches or the Gravels of the world, I just wanted - I think it's unruly having eight candidates on stage and nobody gets their point across.
And Hillary Clinton basically says, well, it was all John Edward's idea.
It was his decision.

For Hillary Clinton, I would think, given the fact that she still remains frontrunner, we could talk about what these polls mean, you know, all these months in advance, but the fact that Hillary Clinton does seem to have a healthy lead over her - the rest of the field, she probably wants as many candidates as possibly to just, you know, have a big field.

Whereas John Edwards and other candidates - like John Edwards, Joe Biden, Chris Dodd, Barack Obama, Bill Richardson - they would love to shorten the field, at least get rid of the Kuciniches and the Gravels who are not showing so well in the polls and so they can go after the sensible frontrunners like Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.
Well, you know, if they want fewer people - if they want more people on stage, If Hillary Clinton wants more people on stage she should switch parties.
Those Republican debates are a cast of thousands.
Well, no actually.
Well, I mean, you have eight Democrats.
You have -now have nine Republicans because Jim Gilmore dropped out.
It was a big shock to people to see Jim Gilmore dropping out.
But also, you'll have Fred Thompson coming in any month now.
I say any month because we - first, we thought he was going to jump into race July 4th, then maybe middle of August.
Now, they're talking about September.
And what's fascinating to me about Fred Thompson, given the fact that he spent hardly anything, you know.
John McCain has gone through 23, 24 million dollars in the last couple of months alone, you know, a tremendous amount of money spent.
Fred Thompson has spent nothing literally.
He's given a couple of speeches, none of which I thought were impressive.
And yet, if you look at the polls, he's up there.
At the last A.P.
poll has him tied just about - just around where Giuliani is in the lead, maybe two points behind Giuliani, and it's remarkable given the fact that he is yet to announce.
He is yet to be specific about anything other than he's tired of the way things are done in Washington.
But apparently, that's enough for these Republican voters.
And what about John McCain?
Is he, I mean, is there - he says he won't get out of the race short of a fatal illness - is the actual quote.
But, he's lost staff.
He's lost cash.

There's a tremendous sadness about watching the John McCain campaign given the fact that - I mean, if you talk about Iraq, a lot of people say that the reason he's doing so poorly is Iraq, well, he's talked about the problems with Bush's Iraq policy for years now.
Three and a half years ago, he called for Donald Rumsfeld's resignation, you know, well before Bush decided to make that move.

But given the fact that he's associated with the failed Iraq policy, given the fact that he supports an immigration policy that an overwhelming majority, the Republican Party, is opposed to, it's no wonder why people are not giving to the McCain campaign.
But, you know, he still likes to cracks jokes, he still has a lot of - the people in the media who support him.
But there is a sadness to him because he really does say what is on the mind, what is on - what's on his mind.
I mean, you could talk about Mitt Romney who is, you know, espousing pro-choice things several years ago and is no longer doing that.

You could talk about Rudy Giuliani who's been kind of all over the map with conservative issues, liberal issues, his record as a New York mayor is contrasting with his record, his proposals as a presidential candidate.
McCain is still nominally the straight shooter he was in 2000, except for the fact that - it's the war and immigration has really taken his candidacy down.
McCain, of course, is not the first candidate to find himself in trouble early in the campaign.
A California Republican by the name of Ronald Reagan had similar problems in his campaign for president.
Craig Shirley is a GOP consultant and a Reagan biographer.
He's on the line with us from his office in Virginia.
Welcome to the show.
Thank you, Rebecca.
How are you?
So, you've been through this before with a candidate like Ronald Reagan.
Do you think it's time for McCain to call it a day?
No.
He's still got these many months before the first primary.
And that's an eternity in politics.
Sometimes a day can be an eternity in politics.
You know, in 1976, Reagan lost the first five primaries to Gerald Ford.
In fact, his campaign was $2 million in debt.
His charter plane was taken away, and he was actually flying a commercial plane.
Can you imagine Ronald Reagan, you know, standing in line like the rest of us with his boarding pass and his ticket?
You know, to trying to wrestle the presidency from Gerald Ford.
Wow, that's great.
How old's Melvin in that picture?
But he'd campaigned tirelessly in North Carolina, won, stunning upset, and came back and stormed into Kansas City and almost pulled off one of the greatest upsets in American politics.
Ironically, he did everything he could to prevent the same thing from happening in 1980, and exactly the same thing happened, where he lost Iowa in a stunning upset by George Bush.
And then again, his campaign was in debt.
He went down by 21 points in North Carolina.
And once again, had to reach deep down inside himself and reconnect with the voters.
And once again, pulled off a stunning win, which then propelled him to the nomination.
So, there's a lot of time for John McCain as there was for Ronald Reagan.
So what sort of advice would you give him?
Get back to basics.

Remember that the first three letters of the word consultant, that, you know, I used to - many years ago, I used to work for the New York Racing Association, we were saying around the track that a good jockey cannot make a bad horse win, but a bad jockey can make a good horse lose.
Most of these campaigns that crash and burn are as much the fault of the consultants as they are anything.
John McCain's strong suit is his integrity and his honesty, and that's where he needs to campaign on.
He needs to make corruption - corruption of Washington, the corruption of the unholy marriage between the Republican Party and the K Street walkers, corporate America, and pound on that everyday.
That is his strongest suit, and that's what people know him to believe, and know that he is a tough son of a gun, and he needs to play to that strength.
He needs to get away from the immigration bill and the other things that he's done that have offended the GOP base and start reconnecting with them on the things that they agree with him on.
Craig, it's Ken Rudin here.
There's a recent A.P.
poll that shows that 23 percent of the responders still do not have a first choice.

And that's pretty unusual for the Republican Party given the history of the Republican Party when people like Nixon, Reagan, both Bushes, Bob Dole, they were the frontrunners and they stuck with the frontrunner.
Why is the Republican electorate having trouble picking a candidate at this point?
Ken, you know, I think the blunt truth is, is that the Republican Party is falling apart at least at the national level.
The grassroots knows what it stands for, and it's always known what it stood for.

The problem is, is that there's nobody at the national level who's really responding to what they want, which is, they came to the Republican Party, you know, through Barry Goldwater, through Bill Buckley, through Ronald Reagan, for reasons of anti-communism, limited government, maximum freedom, personal freedom, personal privacy.
The National Republican Party has not addressed these concerns or many of these concerns for Republicans for many, many years.
And so, it's not surprising that they are choosing, you know, none of the above or just parking their votes and their support and their money on the sideline until somebody emerges.
You know, it's funny, we always talk about a Republican candidate, you know, especially Richard Nixon who, you know, ran as the law and order candidate.
Well, you know, in Fred Thompson, Republicans are - might get a law and order candidate.
Craig Shirley is a Republican consultant.
He worked on the presidential campaign of Ronald Reagan.
Thank you so much for joining us.
My pleasure.
Thank you.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Ken Rudin, how much could or should we be giving to any poll at this point in a campaign?
Well, I love that question because that's a very important question.
Four years ago at this point, the Democratic frontrunner, yeah, I love that word, frontrunner, considering the fact that nobody has voted yet, four years ago, it was Joe Lieberman.
Ten days before the Iowa caucuses in 2004, the leader was Howard Dean, second place was Richard Gephardt, and they finished third and fourth respectively.
So it's kind of interesting the fact that we're talking about frontrunners at this point.
But the Republican Party is historically known for having leaders, you know, and it's the Democrats who have the problem.
It was the Jimmy who, when Jimmy Carter came out of nowhere in '76.
Nobody knew who George McGovern.
Bill Clinton didn't get in the race in the '92 campaign until October of '91.
So, you know, it's unusual to see the Republicans in this point.

But given the fact that the war is so unpopular, given the fact that President Bush and a lot of the establishment Republicans support an immigration bill that the rank and file do not support, it's no wonder that a lot of Republicans are sitting home, both with their checkbooks and their support.
You mentioned Joe Lieberman, which is my segue to this e-mail from Keith(ph) in Sta.
Cruz who says, have any of the Democratic or Republican candidates publicly or privately stated they'd be interested in the position of vice president if offered?
And have any of the same candidates, other than Bill Richardson, said that they would not accept the position of vice president?

Well, actually Chris Dodd announced today that he'd rather stay in the Senate than be vice president, which makes complete sense, because you assume if there's going to be a presidential - the Democrat frontrunners, even it'd be Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama, a lot of people feel, and they may not take a fellow senator from the northeast as their running mate.
But, you know, John Edwards, I think the reason so many people feel that John Edwards is such a strong candidate is because he accepted the vice presidential nomination in 2004.
It gave the American people a chance to see what he's like, and then they have the opportunity to cast him as a presidential candidate in 2008.
It's hard to make the case that any Democrat, given the fact that this 2008 looks like a big Democratic year, for any Democrat to say no to the vice presidency.
We were talking earlier this hour about YouTube and the influence of these videos.
Have you seen the Obama girl and Giuliani girl videos, Ken, on the Web?
I have seen it, yes.
